repnme.cdata!:
Angola - Economic Management Technical
            Assistance Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Economic Management
            Technical Assistance (EMTA) Project for Angola were as
            follows: outcomes were moderately unsatisfactory, risk to
            development outcome was high, Bank performance was
            moderately unsatisfactory, and borrower performance was also
            modernly unsatisfactory. Some lessons learned included: EMTA
            ownership waxed and waned over the course of the loan and
            was especially weak at the end of the project when turnover
            and inability to provide final output data were especially
            problematic. The relatively slow start-up and lack of
            disbursement might have been mitigated by preparing
            procurement processes as part of credit preparation and
            providing training to the project implementers. Additional
            supervision resources are likely to be needed. There is no
            indication this was done. The Bank and Government should
            work to minimize team turnover. Client turnover at the
            beginning and end of the project were problems otherwise the
            situation was stable. Having long serving Task Managers
            residing in country for such a difficult project/country
            situation is highly desirable. Building relationships,
            working through problems, maintaining close contact
            -something that would not have been possible from outside
            the country proved essential. Lessons Learned are important
            and are ignored at the team's risk. A number of the
            lessons above if taken more seriously would have benefited
            EMTA. Operationally, investments in procurement capacity are
            important. Preparing procurement processes prior to approval
            can also help.

docna.cdata!:
Angola - Economic Management Technical
            Assistance Project

repnme.cdata!:
Angola - Economic Management Technical
            Assistance Project : restructuring

abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the Economic Management
            Technical Assistance Project for Angola is to support the
            government effort to improve efficiency and transparency of
            public resources management, by improving the imitational
            framework and building capacity in relevant public
            institutions to articulate and implement public investment
            and financial policies and processes. The team considers the
            reallocation: 1) as a project change within the meaning of
            OP/BP 13.05 (project supervision); 2) does not involve the
            use of cost of project savings, specifically as per footnote
            three to OP 13.25; and 3) does not involve any new change to
            the original project description. Further, the team
            considers the reallocation to be a minor one within the
            meaning of OP/PB 13.05. Finally, the reallocation will not
            result in significant changes to the project's
            description, objectives, or associated outcome targets.

display_title.display_title:
Angola - Economic Management
            Technical Assistance Project : restructuring : Main report

repnme.cdata!:
Angola - Economic Management Technical
            Assistance Project : restructuring

abstracts.cdata!:
The Economic Management Technical
            Assistance Project (EMTA) supports Government of Angola
            (GoA) efforts to improve efficiency and transparency of
            public resource management, by improving the institutional
            framework and building capacity in relevant public
            institutions to articulate and implement public investment
            and financial policies and processes. The recipient had
            initially requested an extension of another 12 months but,
            upon consultation with the country management unit has
            agreed, in principle, to a shorter extension of two months
            so that the project can be restructured. Under the
            restructuring the undisbursed funds will be canceled and
            reallocated to another well performing project in the
            country portfolio. If this request for extension is granted,
            the accumulative extensions will add up to a total of 38
            months, which includes a first extension of 24 months
            granted on May 28, 2007 and a second extension of 12 months
            granted on December 22, 2009. With this extension, the total
            life of the project will be 8 years. The Borrower has
            reaffirmed its commitment to the project activities and the
            willingness to restructure the project and request the
            cancellation of undisbursed credit funds of approximately
            US$ 4 million in order to allow the consolidation of the
            country portfolio, with the understanding that cancelled
            undisbursed funds will be reallocated to another well
            performing project in the country portfolio which will need
            additional financing as part of its own restructuring. The
            implementing entities are in full compliance with the
            Bank's financial management requirements, and there are
            no overdue audit reports and interim financial report from
            these entities.

display_title.display_title:
Angola - Economic Management
            Technical Assistance Project : restructuring : Main report

repnme.cdata!:
Angola - Second-Order Restructuring of the
            Economic Management Technical Assistance Project

abstracts.cdata!:
This Project Paper seeks the approval of
            the Executive Directors to introduce changes including
            accompanying amendments to the project's legal
            documents in the Angola, Economic Management Technical
            Assistance Project (EMTA). With a reformulation of the
            project development objectives (DO), the changes are meant
            to: (a) clarify the DO and results that EMTA is supporting,
            (b) modify the project performance indicators to ensure
            alignment with results by dropping some and adding new
            performance indicators, (c) adapt activities planned to the
            current situation by dropping activities and adding a few
            ones, (d) reallocate the Credit, and (e) provide an adequate
            time frame for seeking clearly defined sustainable results
            by extending the closing date by 24 months from December
            31,2007 to December 31,2009. The main reasons for
            restructuring are the following. a) Design. Project
            preparation was accelerated after the April 2002 Peace
            Accords to ensure Bank's support through this operation
            would be swiftly available. At that time, the need to speed
            up preparation led to some design issues, essentially an
            over-ambitious project in scope with very optimistic
            disbursements projections, a large number of activities and
            low cost estimates; b) Implementation. The project suffered
            from a lack of stable leadership on both the Bank's and
            Government side. This situation led to a slowdown in the
            first months and low initial disbursement. This initial
            delay makes it necessary to adjust the timeline; c) Changing
            environment. The various governmental programs meant to be
            supported by EMTA were not implemented as scheduled; and d)
            Demonstrated commitment and ownership.

Angola - Second-Order Restructuring of the
            Economic Management Technical Assistance Project

repnme.cdata!:
Angola - Economic Management Technical
            Assistance Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Economic Management Technical
            Assistance Project for Angola aims to strengthen the
            Government's capacity to formulate sound analysis and
            to implement sound policies in areas which are critical to
            the management of public resources, including: poverty
            analysis; setting-up a monitoring and evaluation system;
            formulation of a sound Public Investment Program (PIP); and
            the establishment of a more transparent and efficient public
            finance framework. The project will focus on key economic
            policy implementation agencies: Ministry of Planning
            (MINPLAN), Ministry of Finance (MINFIN), and the Central
            Bank of Angola (BNA). The project components are: 1)
            planning component will support efforts at establishing
            methodologies for the preparation, execution and monitoring
            of sector and provincial plans and the PIP; 2) statistics
            component will support the implementation of the recently
            prepared Five-Year Plan for Statistics; 3) public finance
            component will support the MINFIN's public finance
            modernization program; and 4) Central Bank operations
            component (BNA) will continue supporting improvement of BNA
            operations and the full implementation of Angola's
            payment system. The ultimate goal of this project is to
            facilitate the establishment of the appropriate policy and
            governance framework for sustained medium-term growth, in
            the wake of the transition from civil war to peace.

Angola - Economic Management Technical
